verses.text: At that time Herod the Tetrarch heard the reports about Jesus.
verses.comment: Herod hears of Jesus’ growing fame, setting the stage for increased tension between secular rulers and Jesus' ministry, reminiscent of Old Testament prophetic opposition (cf. Elijah and Ahab, 1 Kings 18:17).

verses.text: And he said to his servants, 'This is John the Baptist. He has been raised from the dead! That is why these miraculous powers are at work in him.'
verses.comment: Herod’s superstition leads him to believe Jesus is John returned from the dead, highlighting early misconceptions about resurrection and foreshadowing Christ’s own resurrection.

verses.text: For Herod had arrested John, bound him, and put him in prison because of Herodias, his brother Philip’s wife.
verses.comment: John’s arrest is due to his prophetic witness against sin. The parallel with prophetic persecution in the Old Testament (cf. Jeremiah) is significant, showing the cost of fidelity to truth.

verses.text: For John had repeatedly told him, 'It is not lawful for you to have her.'
verses.comment: John upholds moral law based in the Mosaic covenant, demonstrating the continuity between Old Testament ethics and Jesus’ call to holiness.

verses.text: Although Herod wanted to put John to death, he feared the crowd, because they regarded John as a prophet.
verses.comment: John’s recognition as a prophet by the people affirms his role as a bridge between the old and new covenants, a precursor to Christ.

verses.text: But when Herod’s birthday came, the daughter of Herodias danced before them and pleased Herod.
verses.comment: Herod's weakness leads him to act unjustly, contrasting earthly rulers’ frailty with the steadfastness called for in Christ’s followers.

verses.text: So he promised with an oath to give her whatever she asked.
verses.comment: Herod's rash oath echoes Old Testament warnings about foolish vows (see Judges 11:30-39, Jephthah’s vow).

verses.text: Prompted by her mother, she said, 'Give me here on a platter the head of John the Baptist.'
verses.comment: The sinister influence of Herodias is contrasted with the purity of John’s mission. The martyrdom of John points ahead to Christ’s own sacrificial death.

verses.text: The king was distressed, but because of his oath and his guests, he ordered it to be granted.
verses.comment: Herod’s fear of man overrules righteousness—a spiritual lesson about the danger of seeking the approval of others above God.

verses.text: So he sent and had John beheaded in the prison.
verses.comment: The martyrdom of John anticipated Christ’s own death. Early Christians venerated John as the last and greatest prophet before Jesus.

verses.text: His head was brought on a platter and given to the girl, and she brought it to her mother.
verses.comment: This gruesome act highlights the stark difference between earthly power and the sacrificial nature of true prophetic witness.

verses.text: John’s disciples came and took his body and buried it. Then they went and reported to Jesus.
verses.comment: John’s disciples show reverence for the departed, a practice continued in Christian tradition respecting the bodies of the saints (see Acts 8:2).

verses.text: When Jesus heard what had happened, he withdrew from there by boat to a solitary place. But when the crowds heard it, they followed him on foot from the towns.
verses.comment: Jesus’ withdrawal shows his full humanity in mourning, but also his compassion as he continues his ministry for the people.

verses.text: When he came ashore, he saw a large crowd, and he was moved with compassion for them and healed their sick.
verses.comment: Jesus’ compassion fulfills Old Testament prophecy about the Messiah’s healing ministry (Isaiah 53:4, Matthew 8:17).

verses.text: When evening came, the disciples came to him and said, 'This is a remote place and the day is now over. Send the crowds away so they can go into the villages and buy food for themselves.'
verses.comment: The disciples’ concern for practical needs opens a display of Jesus’ divine provision, reminiscent of God’s provision of manna in the wilderness (Ex. 16:4).

verses.text: But Jesus said to them, 'They do not need to go away. You give them something to eat.'
verses.comment: Christ challenges the disciples’ faith, inviting them to participate in his supernatural work—an enduring model for ministry and dependence on Christ.

verses.text: They said to him, 'We have only five loaves and two fish here.'
verses.comment: The smallness of their resources underscores the sufficiency of Christ in providing for his people.

verses.text: He said, 'Bring them here to me.'
verses.comment: Jesus draws the resources to himself, foreshadowing the offering of bread in communion with him.

verses.text: He directed the crowd to sit down on the grass. Taking the five loaves and the two fish, and looking up to heaven, he blessed and broke the loaves and gave them to the disciples. Then the disciples gave them to the crowd.
verses.comment: Jesus’ actions closely parallel the words and gestures of the Last Supper (Matt. 26:26), showing high christology—he acts as provider, priest, and mediator. The blessed bread foreshadows sacred traditions continuing this imagery.

verses.text: They all ate and were satisfied, and the disciples picked up twelve baskets full of broken pieces that were left over.
verses.comment: The abundance symbolizes the superabundance of grace (cf. Eph. 3:20). The twelve baskets hint at the apostolic foundation of the Church, continuing the legacy of Israel’s twelve tribes.

verses.text: Those who ate were about five thousand men, besides women and children.
verses.comment: The reference to men, with a much larger total number including women and children, shows the vast reach of Jesus’ ministry.

verses.text: Immediately he made the disciples get into the boat and go ahead of him to the other side, while he dismissed the crowds.
verses.comment: Jesus’ authority in directing both disciples and crowds presents him as true shepherd and leader.

verses.text: After he had dismissed the crowds, he went up on the mountain by himself to pray. Evening came, and he was there alone.
verses.comment: Jesus’ withdrawal for prayer exemplifies communion with the Father, modeling the necessity of prayer for spiritual leadership and unity.

verses.text: But the boat was already a considerable distance from land, battered by the waves because the wind was against it.
verses.comment: The disciples’ struggle highlights human vulnerability and the necessity of Christ’s aid in the storms of life.

verses.text: Shortly before dawn, Jesus went out to them, walking on the lake.
verses.comment: Jesus walks on water—an explicit display of divine authority over nature, connecting to Old Testament depictions of God’s mastery of the sea (Job 9:8).

verses.text: When the disciples saw him walking on the lake, they were terrified, saying, 'It’s a ghost!' And they cried out in fear.
verses.comment: Their fear shows human limitations and lack of spiritual understanding, a common challenge for followers of Christ encountering the supernatural.

verses.text: But immediately Jesus spoke to them, saying, 'Take courage! It is I. Do not be afraid.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ self-identification—'It is I' (Greek: ego eimi)—alludes to divine self-revelation in Exodus 3:14, an indirect high christological claim.

verses.text: Peter answered him, 'Lord, if it is you, command me to come to you on the water.'
verses.comment: Peter’s bold request shows the faith and authority found in responding to Christ’s invitation, highlighting the importance of trust and obedience.

verses.text: 'Come,' he said. So Peter got down from the boat, walked on the water, and came toward Jesus.
verses.comment: Jesus empowers Peter to share in his miracle, showing participation in the divine nature by faith (see 2 Peter 1:4).

verses.text: But when he saw the wind, he became afraid, and beginning to sink, cried out, 'Lord, save me!'
verses.comment: Peter’s cry mirrors Old Testament prayers (cf. Psalm 69:2), demonstrating a dependency on Jesus as savior.

verses.text: Immediately Jesus reached out his hand and took hold of him, saying, 'You of little faith, why did you doubt?'
verses.comment: Jesus’ gentle rebuke reminds us of the role of faith in receiving divine assistance.

verses.text: And when they climbed into the boat, the wind died down.
verses.comment: Christ's presence brings peace, symbolizing his authority over chaos and disorder.

verses.text: Then those in the boat worshiped him, saying, 'Truly you are the Son of God.'
verses.comment: The disciples explicitly recognize Jesus’ divinity, a central claim of the Gospel and fulfillment of messianic prophecy (Psalm 2:7).

verses.text: When they had crossed over, they came to land at Gennesaret.
verses.comment: Gennesaret was known for fertile land and healing, a fitting place for the next display of Jesus’ power.

verses.text: And when the people of that place recognized him, they sent word throughout the whole region and brought to him all who were sick.
verses.comment: Popular recognition of Jesus underscores his reputation as healer and miracle worker, fulfilling messianic expectations.

verses.text: They begged him to let the sick just touch the edge of his cloak, and all who touched it were healed.
verses.comment: The healing power of Christ's physical presence anticipates deeper spiritual truths, including the importance of sacraments as means of grace and healing.
